greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1) = 1; for n > 1, a(n) = the smallest prime divisor of the number C(n) formed from the concatenation of 1,2,3,... up to n.
comment: Least prime factor of A007908(n). For 1 < n <= 5000, a(n) < A007908(n), but this should fail infinitely often (assuming standard heuristics). - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Apr 10 2014
link: Robert G. Wilson v, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000 (first 120 terms from Robert Israel)
example: a(5)= 3, 3 is the smallest prime divisor of 12345.
maple: T:=proc(t) local x, y; x:=t; y:=0; while x>0 do x:=trunc(x/10); y:=y+1; od; end:
P:=proc(q) local a,b,n; b:=1; print(1); for n from 2 to q do b:=n+b*10^T(n);
a:=sort([op(divisors(b))]); print(a[2]); od; end: P(100); # _Paolo P. Lava_, Apr 30 2014
mathematica: a = {}; b = {}; Do[w = RealDigits[n]; w = First[w]; Do[AppendTo[a, w[[k]]], {k, Length[w]}]; p = FromDigits[a]; AppendTo[b,First[First[FactorInteger[ p]]]], {n, 25}]; b (* _Artur Jasinski_, Apr 04 2008 *)
program: print1(N=1);for(n=2,100,N=N*10^#Str(n)+n; print1(", "lpf(N))) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Apr 10 2014
results.author: _Amarnath Murthy_, Sep 01 2002
